results.title: The Animals of Farthing Wood
results.creator_credit: EBU, BBC, John Mills, Elphin Lloyd-Jones and Philippe LeClerc
results.brief_description: This is a series of animated films about the animals of Farthing Wood and their journey. Kestrel brings news that the humans are filling in the pond, and with no source of water, they would surely die. Toad advises that they should head for the nature reserve at White Deer Park. They set off on a very long journey, full of adventure and excitement. Based on the bestselling books of Colin Dann.

results.title: The Animals are crying
results.creator_credit: PMS Films, Paul Martin Smith and Peter Beltz
results.brief_description: This film shows how pet owners fail to understand the responsibility of raising animals by telling about the garbage men who almost discard a box until they realise there are live kittens in it. Also suggests owners spay their female cats. (Short version). Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: The Animal movie
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Sidney Goldsmith, Grant Munro and Ron Tunis
results.brief_description: An animated cartoon to help children explore why and how animals move as they do. A little boy discovers that he cannot compete with animals - monkey, snake, horse etc - by imitating the way they move. He only outdistances them when he climbs into a vehicle that can travel in any environment - proving that, while other animals are trapped by their environment, man, the inventor, isn’t. An award winning film.

results.title: The Angry decade (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Brian Adams
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. A look at Australia’s ‘angry young men’ - painters of the Depression Era: Danila Vassilieff, Sidney Nolan, Albert Tucker, John Perceval and Arthur Boyd. Narrated by Robert Hughes.

results.title: The Angelic conversation
results.creator_credit: BFI, James MacKay and Derek Jarman
results.brief_description: As fourteen of Shakespeare’s sonnets are being read we watch a young man isolated in a landscape of fierce physical terror. It is his confrontation with another man - at first antagonistic, then hesitant, and finally sexual - which liberates the man and his environment: rocks turn to water, physical struggle turns to creativity. This beautifully shot experimental film is a love poem dedicated to the artist’s muse; this time the love celebrated is between men and the artist’s liberation is defiantly homoerotic. The sonnets are read by Judi Dench. The atmospheric music score is by the avant-garde British group Coil.

results.title: The Angel and the Soldier Boy
results.brief_description: On her birthday a little boy is given a piggy bank with a shiny new coin, a picture book and two dolls, an angel and the soldier boy. She makes sure the angel and the soldier boy are safe on her pillow but at night the pirates jump out of the picture book and steal the coin from the piggy bank. The noise wakes the soldier and he chases after them and is taken prisoner. When the angel wakes she goes in search and knows there is something wrong when she finds his sword by the empty piggy bank. Rated: G

results.title: The Angel and the devil = Tian shi yu mo gui
results.creator_credit: Pearl River Film Studio and Ling Qiwei
results.brief_description:
Zheng Tian and his gangster friends live life on stealing and robbery. Zheng Tian believes that human nature is half good and half evil, and therefore, his life has two sides. On the one hand, he likes to help people, on the other hand, he commit crimes. Once at a metro station, Zheng Tian comes across a girl who has similar experience as Zheng Tian but has now cut off from her past. The two fall in love and decide to have a new life. But Zhen Tian is tempted by his friends to commit crimes again and is arrested. His girlfriend becomes a member of the Buddhism Association. Zheng Tian understands how his girlfriend has suffered and writes a film script based on his true stories in prison. Towards the end of Zheng Tian’s jail term, he is chosen to play himself in the film and Zheng Tian wants to start a new life with his girlfriend. The film stars Chen Baoguo, who is a leading actor in China and has appeared in many films and TV series.

The film is adapted from well-known Chinese writer, Wang Shuo’s popular novel Half Flame, Half Seawater. Wang Shuo’s work has been translated into many languages and most of his novels have been adapted into films, for example In the Heat of the Sun (dir. Jiang Wen, 1994), Little Red Flowers (dir. Zhang Yuan, 2006) and so on. This film shows that before the 1990s, a lot of PRC films have educational purposes. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; December 16, 2010)
